text: The grave of Sir Douglas Hardie, Western Cemetery, Dundee Sir Douglas Fleming Hardie CBE FRIAS FRSA LLD (1923-2005) was an influential 20th century Scottish businessman who instigated the Tay Road Bridge and other Dundee-based projects. He was Chairman of CBI Scotland and Dayco UK. He was responsible for the relocation of RSS Discovery to Dundee.https://companycheck.co.uk/director/900043274/SIR-DOUGLAS-FLEMING- HARDIE/summary ==Life== RRS Discovery, in Dundee in 2009. Tay Road Bridge He was born on 26 May 1923. He was the son of John M. Hardie of the jute merchants Hardie & Smith who owned the Baltic Linen Works on Annfield Road in Dundee. The family lived at Grayfield House at 62 Annfield Road, close to the factory.Dundee Post Office Directory 1911 He was educated at Glenalmond College. His potential university career was hijacked by the events of World war II. In 1941 he joined the British Army and went to Sandhurst Military Training College to train as an officer. He then joined the 1st Battalion Fife and Forfar Yeomanry, a specialist tank battalion. At the D-Day landings he was part of advanced tank operations using flamethrower tanks to clear German positions. he was demobbed in 1946 at the rank of Major.Scotsman (newspaper) obituary 29 July 2005 He was the youngest ever Deacon of the Nine Trades of Dundee. In the early 1960s he began lobbying the Secretary of State for Scotland (both Michael Noble and Willie Ross) to build a road bridge across the River Tay to link Dundee to Fife. Despite government opposition, he gathered enough local agreement to establish the principle, leading to the opening of the bridge in 1966.Glasgow Herald (newspaper) obituary 9 July 2005 In 1976 he became Chairman of the CBI in Scotland. He was a company Director of multiple Scottish companies and bodies including the Clydesdale Bank and Princes Trust.https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/HJflfVjLulmqhbTz3m_17YzeUAc/appointments From 1979 to 1992 he was a prominent member of the Scottish Development Agency. He was also on the board of Grampian Television, the North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board and Winston Churchill Memorial Trusts. In 1985, in conjunction with the Dundee Heritable Trust, he organised a revitalisation of the docks, centred on the securing of Scott's RSS Discovery. It is now the primary tourist destination in Dundee.https://www.rrsdiscovery.com/plan-your- visit/ He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 1990 for services to Scottish industry.London Gazette 1 January 1990 In 2001 Japan awarded him the Order of the Rising Sun for creating business links between Scotland and Japan.Glasgow Herald, 9 July 2005 In later life he lived at 6 Norwood Terrace in Dundee.https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/HJflfVjLulmqhbTz3m_17YzeUAc/appointments He died in his Dundee home on 7 July 2005. He is buried in the Western Cemetery, Dundee. The simple grave lies against the second upper terrace wall, towards the west. ==Family== He was married to Dorothy Alice Warner.Grave of Sir Douglas Hardie, Western Cemetery, Dundee ==References== Category:1923 births Category:2005 deaths Category:People from Dundee Category:People educated at Glenalmond College Category:Scottish businesspeople Category:20th- century businesspeople
